quoteFirst: There was at the corner of the Rue de Clichy a cabstand which she fixed as the boundary of her promenade. Each time she passed she noticed the clock on the cabstand. First it was
quoteLast: , and more than twenty minutes to wait. Then it was ten minutes to four, and she had ten minutes to wait. Four o’clock struck. They were late.
title: The Blue Duchess
author: Bourget, Paul, 1852-1935; Tristan, Ernest [Translator]

quoteLast: Hotel switchboard operator: "I'm sorry, sir, that number still doesn't answer. Shall I keep trying?"
title: 30-day wonder

title: History for ready reference, Volumes 1 to 5

author: Burton, Richard Francis, Sir, 1821-1890

quoteFirst: Yours has come, my guest, at precisely this moment. It is, if my watch tells me the truth, five and
quoteLast: . It is the last day of April. The year you know. You have exactly one minute to decide whether you will live a short time longer, or whether you will on this last day of April, and before--say, a quarter to four, make that little journey the nature of which you and I have discussed more than once.
title: The Vanished Messenger
author: Oppenheim, E. Phillips (Edward Phillips), 1866-1946

quoteFirst: It is impossible to conceive a wilder prospect, or a more savage and frightful one than this country from the sea, because from every point of view nothing is visible but the summits of rocks; so close to each other that in lieu of valleys there are only fissures between them. From 44 degrees
quoteLast: 2 degrees 8 minutes the aspect varies, the mountains are in the interior, hills and fruitful valleys border the coast.
title:
Celebrated Travels and Travellers, Part 2.
The Great Navigators of the Eighteenth Century
author: Verne, Jules, 1828-1905; Benett, Léon, 1838-1917 [Illustrator]; Matthis, Charles Émile, 1838- [Illustrator]; Philippoteaux, Paul, 1846-1923 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Van Anda, it was possible to see a further extension of the train, making it in all thirty degrees in length. Spurts of light like tiny waves seemed to flow out from the nucleus to a distance of two or three degrees. At
quoteLast: , the writer, on looking downward at the horizon, was startled by what appeared to be a streak of flame, but as it rose higher it proved to be the crescent moon, which with the comet and the planet Venus, completed a wonderful trio. The comet remained visible, resembling a bright star with a slender stream of silvery mist trailing a few degrees after.
title: The romance of comets
author: Proctor, Mary, 1862-1957
